body.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE PETITION OF K. GREGORY, et al.
No. 2646 BRIEF OF PETITIONERS.
Sec. 10. Immigration Act of February 20, 1907 is as follows;

Sec. 10. That the decision of the Board of Special Inquiry, herein provided for based upon the certificate of the examining medical officers shall be final as the the rejection of aliens afflicted with tuberculosis, or woth a loathsome or dangerous contagious diesease, or with any mental or physical disability which would bring such aliens within any of the classes excluded from admission to the United States under this Act.
Sec. 29. of same act is as follows;

Sec. 29- That the Circuit and District Courts of the United States, are hereby invested with full and concurrent jurisdiction of all causes, civil and criminal arising under the provisions of this act.

An examination of Sec. 10. will show, that the decisions of teh examining board is final as to facts which would bring such aliens within any of teh classes excluded by the statue and of course the examining board could have no jurisdiction over any other facts. It is elementary that when the Statute prescribes certain essential facts all other facts are excluded. In other words if these petitioners are not excluded by the Statute they can not by lawfully excluded at all.

It is also elementary that the courts will take jurisdiction in all cases where the Constitution, or the statuts are violated, and an act of Congress excluding such jurisdiction (if there would be such an act) would be unconstitutional and void.

It is also elementary, that an act of congress conferring arbitrary power upon the examining board, or upon any body would be unconstitutional and void. Congress itself has no such power, but all acts of congress are subject to the Constitution; arbitrary power cannot be lawfully exercized within the United States.
Justice Matthew Slate of the Supreme Court of the United States says:
"Any act of the legislature which confers arbitrary power is void."
"The laws and principles upon which our Government rests; forbid the exercise of of arbitrary power", "Acts conferring arbitrary powerr do not belong to the domain of law, and are always and void."
Yick Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356.
There are no lawful grounds for excluding these immigrants. If they can be excluded all immigrants may be excluded, and the Statute nullified.
All actions outside of the Statute is unwarranted, arbitrary and unconstitutional, and if such things are permitted, our government ceases to be a government of law and becames a government of men.
1st. It appears upon the return that there are no Statutory grounds for excluding petitioners.

2nd. The decision of the board is based upon grounds that are irrelevant, and immaterial, and outside of the jurisdiction of
of the board, and unsupported by evidence, and not true, and it may be added that the assumed facts are contrary to the knowledge of all well informed persons.

As for instance the Statute does not exclude "because they are farm laborers and there is no work for them in the United States" This is absurd and foolish. it is a matter of common knowledge that there is a scarcity of farm laborers in the United States. And of like character is the second ground. "Because they have but a limited amount of money, insufficient to maintain them during the winter".
This is an arbitrary assumtion not warranted by facts.

And 3rd- and 4th, grounds are the same. "Because that 800, to a 1000 Russians are unemployed in Seattle, and thousands of other nationalities in the same conditions, and reports from the Interior are to the same effect that the supply of common labor is far in excess of demand".

This is discriminating against the Russians, which is unconstitutional, and seeks to charge them with things they are not responsible. It is also a mistake to assume that farm laborers are common laborers. They are specialists much needed in the United States.

"That any addidtion to the unemployed should be guarded against, and alien laborers should not be permitted to enter the United States at these times".

This is most extraordinary: It is userping all the powers and Function of our government. It is entirely outside the domain of law, and in the realm of the lawless. If statury officials are despots, we are in bad shape. The Immigration officers have made this a political question, and the alleged grounds for excluding the petitioners are politics and not law.

The brief of the respondents contain no authority in conflict
with Sec. 10 of the Statut, Supra.

Your Honor has very properly decided in the Mullah Sing case that, "The jurisdiction of the Court is limited to ascertaining whether the petitioners were denied a lawful hearing, and whether they were excluded upon Statutory grounds".
And of like import are all the authorities cited, so far as they are in point. An examination will show that they conform to Sec. 10 of the Statute, Supra.
Of course a "HEARING", means a lawful hearing upon statutory grounds.

The contention of the learned counsel for respondents on page 2, and 3, of their brief "THAT IF PETITIONERS HAVE HAD A HEARING TAHT IS ALL THERE IS TO BE DONE, THAT IT MAKES NO DIFFFERENCE WHETERH THE HEARING WAS FAIR, OR UNFAIR, LAWFUL OR UNLAWFUL, AND THAT THE STATUTE AND CONSTITUTION ARE INOPERATIVE, AND DOES NOT CONTROL THE ACTS OF THE RESPONDENT, AND THE PETITIONERS HAVE NO RIGHT WHICH THE RESPONDENT IS BOUND TO RESPECT".
In other words, the learned counsel content for anarcy lawless ness and uncontrolled action of Statutory officials.
Sec. 25. of the Immigration act applies to case where the alien has been excluded from admission to the United States by any law or treaty. (Respondents' brief, page 4)

The learned counsel ignores the provision of the Statute, that an alien must be excluded under some law of the United States, and he Seems to contend that an alien may be excluded by the arbitrary act of the examining board, or commissioner. The learned counsel fails to discriminate between the arbitrary and vicious acts of the Statutory officials, and the just and humane processes of the law, based
on natural justice and the constitution and the laws of the land.

Such reasoning is not in point and not in harmony with the law-the petitioners must be excluded by the law, if at all and the proceedings prescribed by the immigration acts must be substancially followed.

There can be no controversy as to the law governing, this case sec. 10 Supra, states the law concisely. If the petitionaries were excluded upon statutory grounds there would be no question about the law in this case; but we contend that they were not excluded upon statutory grounds. As appears from the return of the respondent, and if our contention is true thee can be no doubt about the law in the case, and the only issue in this case is as to validity of the grounds of exclusion as stated in the return of the respondent, and it seems to us that the law is so plain that citations are superflous.

The learned counsel for respondents say on page 6 7 and 8 of their brief that it is admitted that petitioners had a lawful hearing before the examining board. This we deny most emphatically, and contend that the alleged hearing wa not within the law, but entirely outside of the law, and in contemplation of the law it was no hearing at all. The allege grounds of exclusion are not statutory nor lawful., Sec 10, Supra and not amon the grounds specified by Statute, upon which aliens may be excluded.
This is the vital issue in the case at bar-.

When Statutory officials go outside of their authority, they cease to be officials, and are responsible for their acts to the same extend as though they were not officials, but the acts of wrong doers over which it is the duty of the Courts to exercize supervision
Sheriffs, Marshalls, and all persons acting under lawful authority must conform to their lawful authority., and they exceed their authority at their peril.
ALWAYS IN OPERATION

The constitution and the laws of the land are always in operation, They can not be suspended at all by any known individual. Niether the government itself-not congress, nor the courts, nor the Statutory officials, can suspend the law of the land for one instant. They are always in operation for the protection of all persons within the jurisdiction of the U.S. including aliens, and it is the duty of the courts first, to enforce the constitution and the laws alien under the law just as sacred as the rigts of others, and if they are excluded upon any but statutory grounds in the constitution and the laws of the land are violated.
Respectfully submitted, Parker and Kalina Attorneys for Petitioners
